name: Corsair RM650 (2023) 650 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments:
I got this PSU since it has an excellent efficiency rating on the Cybenetics PSU database for 2% load and 20-80 W loads, meaning it's great at idle (which is what I expect my home server to be doing 90+% of the time).
The box didn't come with a physical user manual, but only showed a QR code where I could get the electronic version online. However, this link was dead, and I can't find the manual anywhere. Not that it actually matters, since installing and using it is pretty straightforward.
It comes with both straight and right angle SATA power cables, which is pretty nice, since you can use whichever helps maintenance and cable management more. The PCIe power cable (for GPUs), however, is just a single cable with a pigtail for two PCIe connectors, which isn't optimal. However, I don't plan on running a powerful GPU with this server at all (maybe a small GPU for transcoding), so it's fine for me.
Otherwise, this PSU works well, no issues.
Great modular design.
Using for a home server/NAS. Works fine. Cables are easy enough to manage. Gold rated, reputable brand for PSUs.
Following the minimum wattage from PCPP, I went this unit. It doesn't randomly shut off and it's quiet. Zero complaints.
Pretty good quality PSU for the price. Only complaint is the cables are very stiff which made building a bit frustrating at times.
Very high quality power supply.
Lables on all the cords making first time building a breeze. Great product.

It gives power. I may have heard it speak up or rattle once or twice, but it‚Äôs definitely not a consistent problem. Good performance absolutely makes up for that one, though.

Looks like a good PSU in terms of modularity and specs, but not noise. My unit has noticeable coil whine and its fan makes a rattling, almost engine-like noise when spinning up to speed. It would've been less noticeable if the fan started with the PC and worked continuously, but instead there's a 130W threshold for silent mode, so any decent workload makes it go on and off pretty often. It's not too bad, but the coil whine is annoying. Might RMA the unit for that.

It's a power supply. What else can I say?
10/10 would buy again. I mean, it's not a low-yield dirty bomb (unlike some other PSUs), so it's great.

name: Segotep GN 650 W 80+ Gold Certified ATX Power Supply
comments: Good power supply you get everything you expect for a fully modular power supply.

I'm a hobby builder. Have purchased at least half a dozen of these over the past six months. Have not had the first issue with any of them. Though they are in PC systems built to be sold. So, I do not have first hand experience on longer term quality or durability. They sound plenty quiet for a US$50 PSU. They look good. All black flat cables.
Segotep is a 20+ year old company. Their 750W & 850W "GM" PSUs are rated "Tier B" at the PSU Cultists Network and "Gold Efficiency" & "A- Noise" at Cybenetics Labs. So, I think the manufacturer has reasonable credibility. I've not seen a better value on a 650W 80+ Gold PSU. Plus, even Corsair & Seasonic have sold "Tier F - replace immediately" units per the PSU Cultists Network. So, brand name is no guaranty either way.
NOTE: The Newegg description is INCORRECT. This unit is NOT ATX 3.0 & PCIe 5.0 Ready. It appears Newegg copied the description from the 750W "GM" PSU rather than this 650W "GN" PSU. The Amazon description looks correct.

As always, DO NOT TRUST USER REVIEWS FOR PSUs. The only way to get objective data on these things is from proper reviewers like Tom's Hardware or Gamers Nexus. Consult the Cultists Tier List Source Spreadsheet for more info, and do not make a purchase based on the subjective data in this review.
That said, this is a solid unit. True SFX, reliable, plenty of wattage*, gets the job done. Fully modular and the cables are nice.
However, it is not quiet, not loud enough to be annoying but audible over good quality CPU/GPU cooling at moderate loads. The advertised semi-passive operation up to 40% load is false; the fan kicks on with a vengeance around 175-200 W of full system draw. My particular example also came with the EPS connectors tangled through each other in a way that was impossible to separate.
*a design flaw causes the 850W version of this unit to get flaming hot at its full capacity. I would personally treat this unit as a 700 W since it has the same component choice.

name: Lian Li EDGE 1300 W 80+ Platinum Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: The edge PSU works perfectly with the King 95 Ultra case. I like how the cables are already braded so you don't have to get extension cables to make the build look good.

Pros:
Cables come braided and have combs on them
L shape design makes plugging in cables a breeze
Comes with a dedicated 12V 2x6 port and cable (the prongs that plug into the GPU and powersupply are bright blue so when you go to install it makes it easy to identify that the plug is all the way in)
Cables come in a nice bag that can be reused to keep spare cables in
The wattage options this power supply comes in
Adds 4 additional ports for USB 2.0 headers to plug into
Cons:
Availability (almost always out of stock)
Mainly designed for dual chamber cases (Ex. Lian Li O11 EVO XL)
Minor Grievances:
-None
Final Thoughts:
This is a very nice power supply from Lian Li. I would absolutely recommend this, only if you are building a PC in a dual chamber case (most cases coming out today are). The L shape makes installing and routing cables a breeze and makes cable management much easier. The cables you will normally see in the front of the PC (24 pin, 8 pin PCI-Es, and 12V 2x6) come braided and have combs on them to keep them organized. Comes with a dedicated 12V 2x6 port and cable, along with a two 8 pin PCI-Es to a 12V 2x6. My only issues is that these power supplies are almost always on back order and never in stock. I got lucky and grabbed mine from a restock on Amazon.

Eventually, we got it in but are planning to order a different, flat power cord that will replace this as one of the pins had come bent inside the cord & we needed to straighten one or two for them even to work. 1300W! My first MSI power supply. Has been rock solid handing my 4090. Cables are very nice. It's a great looking power supply as well if that matters to you.

PSU: MSI Meg 1300Ai
How much will you pay for peace of mind? For me, a lot. Shouldn't need to upgrade for years. Cables all looks good and clipped in easily. Time will tell if it was worth the premium.

This PSU got a lot of great reviews. I like to use Seasonic or EVGA brands but couldn't pass up the reviews on this one. Also my choices were limited because I needed a PSU with a 12hvpwr connection for the 4K GPU's, and didn't have the range of choice I usually do.

Excellent build quality - stays in absolute silent mode for most applications.
Perfect fit of the 12V / 600W cable with the MSI Suprim Liquid.

name: Lian Li SP850 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular SFX Power Supply
comments: ig it works?
Made me go deaf and lose 2 acres of crops

Cables were nice and plyable, great for working in the tight spaces in the Dan A4-H20. The lengths of the cables were also great for this case. You definitely want an SFX (not SFX-L) PSU for the Dan A4-H20, you want that extra space.
The PSU is very quite and we weren't able to hear the fan while the system was at full load.

It's a pretty good PSU but I have some problems was the cables, specifically their flexibility. They're not very flexible. On my build, the 2x8 PCIe caused alot of pressure on my GPU mount with how much cord is between the 2 ends and with how rigid it is. But if your build has plenty of space, it's a good PSU to have

name: Corsair RM1200x SHIFT 1200 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular Side Interface ATX Power Supply
comments:
Tier A. Quality PSU that comes with a native 12VHPWR 600W cable. I shouldn't need to get another one for at least 10 years. The included cables are flat so it's easy to bend and get them to fit however you need.
Having the connectors on the side made it easy to swap out 2 regular 8-pin PCIe cables for the 12VHPWR. This also makes building less stressful.
My only minor complaint is the connectors on the PSU side are TINY and somewhat close together after you've connected them so you're gonna need a bit of patience to get them back out.

Oh... my... god!
Everyone should buy the Shift version of Corsair RMx -- The ease of installation is amazing.
Just buy it and see for yourself -- this is a game changer!
Chose this PSU as it was most reasonably priced for its tier. 1200 W is approximately 1.5x total wattage of the build.
Kinda works

The tight cable room in the Lian Li Evo XL case made me pick the SHIFT psu. I took out the top drive cage and routed cables up and over to the inputs. Look is the cable management picture. Can't imagine doing it any other way.

208‚Ç¨ from 240‚Ç¨ on a sale, it's a very great PSU without coil whine and the cables are SLEEK THIN, so are the plugs!. Reaches all places without issues! (My case has a bit more than side panel's space to fit the cables, see the photos!!)
Great power supply. A lot of power and modular.
This PSU is amazing and made wiring a new PC a breeze! It fits really well in a be quiet! Dark Base Pro 901 ATX Full Tower.

Reliable power supply with plenty of wattage to suit my needs. Came with its own 12vhpwr connector so I didn‚Äôt need to use that bulky adapter the gpu came with. New type 5 cables on these psus are slimmer and a lot cleaner looking. Still plan to upgrade to some Cablemod extensions but they are a massive improvement over the bulky connectors they used to use.

name: EVGA 400 N1 400 W ATX Power Supply
comments: Its EVGA. It has to be good. No questions asked
Power was supplied.
Great budget power supply and hasn't blown up.

A lot of people mention this being for Office PCs. Running a Ryzen 2600, 1650 Super on this PSU has been working great. EVGA is a good brand name and 400W is enough for an entry gaming rig. The cables are yellow/black/red which is fine for the price.
After the fact, I saw a video where Linus Tech Tips builds a $500 entry gaming rig with this same PSU. "It's EVGA so it can't be that bad"
Hasn't blown up yet

It's cheap but I don't see this system ever getting north of 100w in its current configuration, maybe 150-200w with upgrades so it should be just fine for this build. I don't think i would go for this psu for any type of gaming PC though.

EVGA and Corsair may be the only PSU brands I actually trust. For me, there isn't much to say about it. It delivers enough wattage, and it works. Your standard 400W PSU. Cables felt a bit short though.
It's from EVGA which I trust always, it's non modular unfortunately, but I had it laying around and it works for what I need it to, I just wish it had more SATA power connectors, it only has 3.
Aside from being the most expensive part and not having a power switch, this is a high quality PSU!

This is a reputable brand and in this case was extremely cheap. Nearly every other brand around this price range is a cheap off brand with nightmarish reviews of PSU failure. Also, it is not a very good idea to skimp out on the PSU, despite it being a budget build I was not going to cut this corner, as much. However, the thought did cross my mind. Sometimes its better to pay the extra money to save possible future headaches. This was one of the rare exceptions. Its non-modular, which makes no difference to me this case will not be opened for a long time, and the aesthetics mean very little . Of course its not modular so that makes cable management a little bit harder, but for the price it went nice with this build.

name: Thermaltake Toughpower GF A3 Snow 1050 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Great bang for the buck, I'm probably at most using half the power it outputs but getting too close to the edge is probably what killed my last computer so I'm expecting a lot of value over this one. All the cables are ALSO white just in case you were worried, and come in neat little bags all bundled up so you can hang onto the ones you don't need right away. It's whisper quiet and if for whatever reason you wanted to there's a fan toggle for automatic or always on. Fits in great with my all white PC!

An insanely powerful PSU that gives you 50 extra watts for the equivalent price of a 1000 PSU from any other brand. Attractive white color, ATX 3.1 compatibility including the dreaded 12V cable connection, and more than enough connections for all of your motherboard, GPU and peripheral needs. Includes premium individually shielded wire cables. Make sure to check that you have the version that is built in China and not Japan.

Very very easy to install into the pc, comes with a bag for the cables and has written scripture for certain parts that go to certain locations like the "CPU cord". The cables are beautiful with the full out white pc and fit in with the aesthetic of the build.
Plenty of power and then some. I like the smart fan options. I only wish the PSU connecting ports were also white . . .
Thermaltake GF A3 Snow is beautiful!!!! sadly it's hidden away in the back, hidden but not forgotten, white cables, silent fan mode, it's PRICELESS!!!!
Great PSU, looks amazing in white with white cables, runs practically silent too!
although the power is 1050 W but I suggest should have taken the 1300 watt model
Never had a thermaltake PSU crap on me and this had the 600W GPU connector spot with white cables and black male female connectors so it works great with white builds!

AFAIK this thing is good (no issues related to powering the 720W expected system load) and appears to be mid-tier on cultists' tier list. It also has solid aesthetics. All I need from a unit is that it keeps going, honestly. My last unit was a Thermaltake supply and it's still fine after 7.5 years so hopefully this one has the long term chops as well.

Wanted to get a white PSU since it already comes with white cables and wouldn't have to get white extensions. Glad I went with a white PSU as it looks better from the back of the case. Easy to install and comes with a nice bag for all the extra cables. Wanted to only pay $150 for a PSU. Was having trouble finding this PSU, but found one on Amazon for around $150 - $170.

name: NZXT C1200 (2024) 1200 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
Apevia Galaxy 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Semi-modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Very surprised by this little baby. Excellent that all the cords that are needed are already attached. Very quiet.
Really cheap for the wattage, I have had no issues with it so far and it seems to carry my 525w build just fine.

name: EVGA 500 W1 500 W 80+ Certified ATX Power Supply
comments: Has everything you need.
I have been using this for about 3-4 years and it has yet to blow up on me >:)
Works well, cables are kinda bulky, non modular, and low efficiency and turns into an artificial sun.
Works well. Cables almost didn't reach needed locations though.

Hasn't blown up in the 8 hours since I built the computer (or at least, not that I've heard yet). On a serious note, it's a decent budget power supply but definitely needs a psu shroud to hide the ludicrous amount of SATA power and molex cables included
Hasn't blown up yet, wish I got a semi or fully modular one though.
Didn't blow up

Being non-modular is definitely pretty annoying, and I kinda wish I paid more for a modular 80+ gold instead. But the power supply works fine and hasn't blown up so far. If you're building something that doesn't need too much power, this will work for you
Ugly cables but works perfectly fine
Haven't had any problems with this psu.

name: Corsair RM1000x (2021) 1000 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Bought it to future proof: it's 1000W, but my build only uses 396W
More than enough juice for any build I've had this PSU in, lasted 3 years so far and still kickin'.
It is a power supply, it does what it is made to.
Good and functioning power supply. Although cables could be a bit better if it comes with a 600W one for the GPU.
The only thing I wish it had was a 4 pin cable for the motherboard but I didn't see it come with any
Did I overbuy with the power supply? Maybe... slaps the side of the case But it is a beautiful piece of equipment.
Arguably the most important part. I needed something high quality and reliable, otherwise all the other parts are useless in the long run. This does the job quietly and extremely well.
all good

power supply
i dont usually hear it but i often have my own room fan on
Delivers all the power I need for my system like a champ.

name: Thermaltake Toughpower GF3 TT Premium 750 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: It performs well and doesn't cost a fortune, 'nuff said. I wish the 12VHPWR connector clicked better so I wasn't scaring myself when I plugged it into the gpu, but I assume the 12V-2x6 revision is better with that, so try to get a PSU with that instead.
Cables are a little stiff but it dosent explode.

This PSU was among the best in the PSU Cultists Tier List. I liked all the cables it provided, more than sufficient for myself. One star removed only because I felt the cables were a bit too tight/rigid to insert/remove, especially the motherboard connection. Apart from that it works really well.

name: Lian Li EDGE GOLD 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Only day 2 with this PSU for me but as of now I love the white cables and the shape of the PSU, makes it easy to plug cables in.

name: Asus TUF Gaming 750G 750 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Nice PSU, no need to buy after market cables since the original are flexible and individually sleeved.

Seems good, ngl thought it died but it was just my power went out lol. The braidedish cables are definitely the highlight, makes any build so much easier and it looks a whole lot better too. The PSU seems competitively price for what it comes with (ATX 3.0 + good cables).
Good power supply, I got this on sale so it was great bang for buck performance.
No frills PSU. I mounted it upside down (fan side up) initially. Ample number of cables provided with nicely braided covers.

name: ADATA XPG Core Reactor II 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: A rock-solid PSU with high efficiency and stable power delivery. Fully modular design makes cable management easy. Runs quiet and has all the necessary protections.
Solid ATX 3.0 PSU. It is very well reviewed considering its price.
Good PSU. It has a ten year warranty, and the cables are good quality as far as I can tell. Very easy to use.

name: MSI MAG A1000GL PCIE5 1000 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Very reliable, love that the 12VHPWR cable has yellow pins: I was likely not gonna run into the melting cable issues with a 5070 Ti anyways but better safe than sorry!
A bit overkill but great steady power

name: be quiet! Dark Power 13 850 W 80+ Titanium Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Very good, too expensive
Clearly labeled outputs, as well as a good supply of well made computer cables. Box for extra cables included for storage.

Lots of user reviews of the Dark Power 13 series where the fan makes a rattling noise while idle. Fortunately my model does not have that issue! Perhaps this was a bad batch last year and Be Queit has now sorted this out. I love this PSU, it has a 135mm Silent Wing fan so is real quiet, even under full load. Sleeved cables that are flexible enough but not individually sleeved. The GPU cable is a pigtail style which I don't like, but I use custom extension cables anyway so not an issue.

I wanted an ATX 3.0 certified power supply for my RTX 4080 and be as energy efficient as possible (80+ Titanium). 850 Watts gives me enough headroom (200W) if all components and attached (charging) peripherals would draw max. power (which they never do), and gives me the optimum efficiency curve. 1000W would be overkill and not be more efficient for the same type of PSU. The ATX 3.0 certification means the 850W can safely and reliably handle the power spikes caused by the new RTX graphics cards. I do not expect me using even more power-hungry components in the future, that would require more than 850W combined.

name: be quiet! Pure Power 11 400 W 80+ Gold Certified ATX Power Supply
comments: was aiming for System Power models but they all had bad grades so I went with this. only significant flaw is that it's not modular so I have to keep that electric spaghetti inside the case
Good quality PSU while being fairly cheap.
I chosed this PSU for its price and the 80+ Gold certificate. In hindsight i would chose the cable managment version of this PSU.

name: Lian Li SP850 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular SFX Power Supply
comments: Saw this was on the b-tier list on PSU cultist and wanted to give it a shot. Having an all white build and finding an all white SFX PSU is hard to come by in stock lately.
Honestly I'm not overly impressed. It looks nice and is definitely a power supply, but the connectors are super tight and hard to unplug, and the cables are way too stiff and rigid.
I LOVE THE CUSTOM Sleeved cables it comes with right out of the box! They are so good if you pair it with some Asiahorse cable combs! Handles my rx 6950 xt power load very well!

Quiet and feels high quality, never tried Lian li for psu's but I would highly recommend for a white sfx psu. The cables have a braided feel and are much higher quality then most power supply brands, so that a big bonus.
UPDATE AS OF NOVEMBER 2024: I would unfortunately be unable to recommend this PSU, since recently during an upgrade, it gave off a foul burning odor, so I never used it since.

Looked for white Psu‚Äôs and this one seemed like a good option at the time . It still is I would argue and would recommend , but unfortunately (And I added the extra 25$ to the price ) I purchased a Mobo EPS Cable and mounting bracket (Sfk > Atx) , which were the additional costs and headache . Overall not bad , just get something else if thats not for you , unless you want a tiny power house :)
4 months of use and no issues with power delivery. The cables aren't very long, routing them to the PSU required full length in my case, but I got cable extensions to clean the build up.

I actually got the 750 Watt white variant, but that is not available on pc part picker.
The 24-pin power cord is very short, which required me to mount it opposite of ideal (fan in) so that it would reach. I'll probably have to go with custom cables at some point.
I do like that the wires are both white and have white connectors, which not all white PSU's went with.
The wires are a nice mix between stiff and flexible.
So far so good, quiet, does what it's supposed to, nice sleek clean look with everything white - fan, connectors, wires.

It is a good looking PSU and has a high wattage. Also has enough cables. The braided cables look really good. The only problem is that the PCIe cables are short, they just barely reached my ASUS ROG STRIX 3070, I had to route the cables from above because they don't reach the connecter from underneath. Some cable extensions are recommended if you are using the Lian Li O11D mini (I don't know if they reach in other cases).

name: Cooler Master MWE Gold 750 V3 750 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular ATX Power Supply
comments: Works great
Great PSU for the price. The 90-degree 12-pin connector is great. It got a B+ on the PSU Tier List.

Didn‚Äôt arrive dead Hasn‚Äôt done any weird noises Works so far
Comes with a lot of cables Got it for $100 Comes with some like 600 watt cable for something, if it doesn‚Äôt come dead, then I recommend buying it

name: Corsair RM850x SHIFT 850 W 80+ Gold Certified Fully Modular Side Interface ATX Power Supply
comments: Awesome idea to have cables route up to add give when managing them. Cables are stiff but bendable and keep shape. Quiet, haven't even heard the fan turn on.

For the cases that can accommodate it, I think the RMx Shift series is a great innovation in consumer PC supplies.
Pros:
performance; Cybenetics-certified Gold Efficiency / A Noise rating
ATX 3.1-certified; includes 2x8-pin PCIe->12V-2x6 adapter.
side-facing cable inputs; facilitates far easier cable access and management compared to the standard PSU layout.
Corsair Type 5 micro-fit cables; notably more compact connectors than the Type 4 predecessor.
fluid dynamic bearing fan
100% Japanese 105 ¬∞C capacitors
10-year manufacturer‚Äôs warranty
Cons:
cost; way over-priced compared to similarly performant 850 W power supplies.
limited compatibility; incompatible with dual chamber fish tank-style cases, or any chassis narrower than 210 mm in width.
lack of native 12VHPWR / 12V-2x6 connector.

The psu was something we worried about a little bit but turned out to be great. The side mounting was also nice and you could sea in the pics how we removed the hdd/ssd pocket to fit the cables in the psu
Little bit over the top, but it gets a job done and it‚Äôs quick with it and it‚Äôs quiet with the fan
Great design
Works great. Let down by horribly stiff and inflexible cabling that made placement and cable management really challenging.
